node.title: Ripe cherries look like this after record rain. What will it mean for Christmas?
node.alt: Cherries damaged on the trees from rain.
node.description: Cherry growers warn consumers may have to pay more for the fruit this Christmas, as unseasonally heavy,  widespread rain wreaks havoc in several growing regions.
node.content:
["Cherry growers warn consumers may have to pay more for the fruit this Christmas, as unseasonally heavy and widespread rain wreaks havoc in several\u00a0growing regions.", "The cherry capital of Young has recorded 216mm of rain during November,\u00a0more than three times the long-term average.", "Too much rain while cherries are ripening can cause the fruit to split and crack making the crop not worth picking.", "Scott Coupland runs a cherry and stone fruit orchard in Young and he is yet to pick any fruit this season because of the rain damage.", "\"I suppose I've never seen a start like this before,\" Mr Coupland said.", "", "
Scott Coupland has lost six early varieties to rain and is yet to pick any fruit.(ABC Rural: Hugh Hogan)
", "Mr Coupland was remaining optimistic that the rain would set up the later varieties for a strong finish to the cherry season.", "Local grower and president of Cherry Growers Australia Tom Eastlake said estimates were\u00a0that more than 50 per cent\u00a0of the Young\u00a0crop had been lost.", "\"But we've had another rain event over the weekend which may see that ratchet higher,\"\u00a0Mr Eastlake said.", "
Widespread rain damage
", "The wet weather has impacted\u00a0growing regions across the country.\u00a0", "", "
President of Cherry Growers Australia Tom Eastlake\u00a0says cherries will likely be more expensive this Christmas.(ABC Rural: Hugh Hogan)
", "Mr Eastlake said the\u00a0Adelaide Hills, Northern Victoria, Central Victoria and the Yarra Valley had\u00a0all experienced some damage, but not to the same extent of Young.", "
Mild spring saves cherries at Orange\u00a0
", "Fiona Hall from BiteRiot said cooler spring temperatures in Orange\u00a0had been the \"saving grace\"\u00a0for her cherries, delaying the harvest and avoiding rain damage.", "Orange recorded more 317mm of rain last month, making it the wettest November in 152 years of records according to Weatherzone.", "\"Anything that's\u00a0turned colour has got damage but that's a hat full of fruit,\" Ms Hall said.", "", "
Fiona Hall from Orange says the mild spring has delayed ripening and saved most of her crop from damage.\u00a0(ABC Rural: Fiona Hall)
", "Ms Hall said the rain should improve the later varieties if it does dry out.", "
Expensive Christmas cherries
", "Cherry Growers president Tom Eastlake said\u00a0there would still be plenty of good quality cherries at Christmas time but the fruit\u00a0would be more expensive than last year.", "\"[The cost]\u00a0will be higher than last year, that's for sure, there's just too much demand and too little fruit.\"", "", "
Some growers are yet to pick any commercial quantities of fruit this season following the constant rain.(ABC Rural: Hugh Hogan)
", "Fiona Hall at Orange said the rain should make for great quality cherries later in the season, if it stopped\u00a0raining.", "\"They might be few and far between but they should be good and they should be a good size and if we get dry weather from here in there should be some cherries.\"", "Tom Eastlake\u00a0said this season would be remembered for a long time among cherry growers."]
